abstracts.cdata!:
The overall project development
            objective (PDO) of the Avian and Human Influenza Control and
            Preparedness Emergency Project is to support the
            implementation of the Cambodia Comprehensive Avian and Human
            Influenza (AHI) National Plan contributing to minimize the
            threat posed to humans and the poultry sector by AHI
            infection in Cambodia, and to prepare for, control, and
            respond if necessary to a human influenza pandemic. The
            changes include: (a) modifications of the results framework;
            (b) a reallocation of Grants proceeds; and (c) certain
            changes to the percentage of financing for the International
            Development Association (IDA) Grant and the AHI Facility
            Grant as well as creation of a new disbursement sub-category
            for the Policy and Human Resources Development (PHRD) Grant.
            Progress towards achievement of the PDO is rated as
            moderately satisfactory, and implementation progress is
            rated as satisfactory. Current disbursements stand at USD
            8,585,587 or 78 percent for all three financing sources
            combined (as of September 30, 2012). The PDO remains
            relevant and is a priority for the Kingdom of Cambodia.
            Continuous efforts are being made in capacity building
            (including training in rapid response, monitoring and
            reporting, and infection control measures) and institutional
            organization, and the pandemic preparedness procedures have
            been established and continue taking hold, together with an
            extension of the technical service contracts with the Food
            and Agriculture Organization (FAO) (for institutional
            strengthening and technical assistance in animal health,
            particularly avian flu) and with the World Health
            Organization (WHO) (for technical assistance and capacity
            building in response to the threat of avian flu).
